text: do you think people have the right to
build a mosque in an Islamic community
center near Ground Zero or don't they
have that right during the last week of
August the New York Times asked this
question and others to nearly 900 New
York City residents were you living in
New York City on September 11th results
of the poll showed that 50 percent of
respondents opposed the proposed
location of a mosque and Islamic Center
near Ground Zero 37 percent of them
strongly meanwhile 35 percent of them
are in favor of the location the rest
are undecided negative feelings towards
Muslims because of the attack on the
World Trade Center or not yes people and
politicians around the country have
weighed in on the decision to put a
mosque here just two blocks from ground
zero
I decided I needed to drive up here just
for this it's a mockery it's a mockery
to our country but New Yorkers have a
particular stake in this issue
The Times asked a handful of poll
respondents to share their thoughts on
camera I think there should be a ground
rule of you can only argue about this or
discuss this if you live within the five
boroughs and you were here on that day
let's just everyone else just shut up
yeah I knew 12 people who died one very
well all from the same company on the
94th floor so yeah I think this
particular location is is insensitive
I actually three over there many times
so I feel is good for religious people
release their rights as the Constitution
say I think they have every right
preferred to be there and I don't really
understand
I mean how people are in such an uproar
about it it just seems like they're
building freedom towers but then they're
taking the freedom of religion and you
know they're right to have that there
and just as such a hypocritical thing I
thought would be better if it was maybe
ten blocks or twelve blocks away because
I sort of felt that this could be a
presence of Muslim activity in case
future terrorists
to come back and destroy a future World
Trade Center building I think they have
a lot of misunderstanding about Islam
and Muslim so that's why they strongly
against them quite frankly if what they
profess to be all about with being a
very peaceful religion and advocating
peace across the board they should
really take the high road and come out
and say since it's causing so much
anxiety you know we'll look at winner
and I think that that should be their
position but as a gay person I think you
know I don't have the right to marry in
New York State yet I support the right
of a religious center that probably
wouldn't approve of my lifestyle but
it's not about approval it's about the
you know live-and-let-live to say that
they can't build their house of worship
where they'd like to is is more of an
injustice to our society than the
atrocities that happen on 9/11 I think
they have the legal right to build it
but I don't know if it's the wisest
thing to do this could even exacerbate
the problem of Muslim hatred in the
United States and all over the world
that in some ways it's victory for them
and I just don't think that we need our
noses rubbed in it you know I think
we've there wasn't a huge backlash after
9/11 which I'm really surprised about
but I think that speaks volumes to the
nature of this country and the freedoms
but I can't guarantee it wouldn't happen
after this you know I just
why Stoke that fire you know I
understand and see the pain that people
are still in it it really isn't that
recent and if you were here in the city
living here on that day of course you
still remember it and absolutely I
remember walking past the houses of two
of my neighbors and they were missing
posters on their door
but to me you know keeping something
sacred and to me the most sacred thing
is that people should be able to
practice their religion and I am very
proud about this country this country's
people are very broad-minded and they
accept everybody so I am proud about
this country so I think this is a simple
issue it is not a big matter
